Smt.Rajni Tiwari vs Municipal Corporation Sagar on 13 August, 2024

Author: 
Vishal Mishra

Bench: 
Vishal Mishra

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 1 W.P. No.9715/2007
 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH
 AT JABALPUR
 BEFORE
 HON'BLE SHRI JUSTICE VISHAL MISHRA
 ON THE 13th OF AUGUST, 2024
 WRIT PETITION No. 9715 of 2007
 SMT. RAJNI TIWARI
 Versus
 MUNICIPAL CORPORATION SAGAR AND OTHERS
 ............................................................................................................................................
 Appearance:
 Ms. Malti Dadariya - Advocate for the petitioner.
 Shri Abhimanyu Singh - Advocate for respondent No.1.

 ............................................................................................................................................
 ORDER

 Since both these petitions are filed by same petitioner arising out
 of the same issue, therefore they are heard analogously and are being
 decided by this common order.

 2. W.P. No.9715/2007 has been filed by petitioner assailing the

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 order dated 15/11/2006 passed by respondent No.1 whereby respondent
 No.3 has been promoted to the post of Lecturer treating her to be senior
 to the petitioner.

 3. It is the case of petitioner that she was initially appointed on the
 post of Upper Division Teacher in Pandit Motilal Nehru Higher
 Secondary School, Sagar vide order dated 23.09.1983. The Recruitment
 Rules relating to recruitment and promotion applicable to the
 Government Teachers are adopted for the recruitment and promotion of
 teachers in the schools run by the Municipal Corporation, Sagar. The
 Municipal Corporation, Sagar is the local authority constituted under the
 
Madhya Pradesh Municipal Corporation Act, 1956
. The services of the
 petitioners are government by Madhya Pradesh Non-Gazetted Class-III
 Education Service (Non-Collegiate Branch) Recruitment and Promotion
 Rules, 1973. In terms of the Rules, the post of Upper Division Teacher
 is a class-III post and as per Schedule-III, Column-5, the required
 qualification for the post of Upper Division Teacher was earlier second
 division in Bachelor Degree which was subsequently amended on
 16.06.1993 and the required qualification as per amendment is second
 class in Bachelor Degree and B.Ed. For the post of Upper Division
 Teacher. It is the case of the petitioner that he was appointed prior to the
 amendment, therefore, she will be governed by the earlier rules.
 Promotion to the post of Lecturer which is notified as Class-II post is
 regulated by the Recruitment rules known as Madhya Pradesh Education
 Service (School Branch) Recruitment & Promotion Rules, 1982. In
 terms of Schedule-I, the Lecturer, Higher Secondary Schools are
 classified as Class-II post. In terms of Schedule-IV, the Upper Division
 Teacher on completion of five years of service will be promoted to the

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 3 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 post of Lecturer, Higher Secondary School. The basis of promotion
 from Class-III to Class-II post shall be seniority-cum-suitability. Thus, it
 is clear that for the post of Upper Division Teacher, the essential
 qualification was second class Bachelor Degree prior to 16.06.1993 and
 after amendment, necessary qualification was second class in Bachelor
 Degree and B.Ed. Petitioner's initial appointment was made as daily
 wage employee on the post of Upper Division Teacher by order dated
 23.09.1983 and was continued on the said post until she was granted
 regular pay-scale on the post of Upper Division Teacher vide order
 dated 24.03.1984. Vide order dated 08.06.1987, petitioner's appointment
 was approved by the Public Service Commission.

 4. It is argued that as the petitioner's appointment was approved by
 the Public Service Commission and as the appointment of the
 respondent No.3 was not approved by the Public Service Commission,
 therefore, respondent No.3 was not eligible to be appointed on the post
 of Upper Division Teacher in the Corporation. Being aggrieved,
 respondent No.3 preferred a petition being M.P. No.519/1986 which
 was dismissed observing that she is third division in Higher Secondary
 as well as third Division in Graduation, therefore, she was rightly not
 appointed to the post of Upper Division Teacher. Therefore, she was not
 eligible to hold the post of Upper Division Teacher. Her services ought
 to have been counted from the date when the Public Service
 Commission has affirmed her services on the post of Upper Division
 Teacher.

 5. It is argued that respondent No.3 has passed the Bachelor degree
 in third division, therefore, she was not entitled to be given appointment
 on the post of Upper Division Teacher coupled with the fact that

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 4 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 appointment of respondent No.3 is not approved by Public Service
 Commission. The appointment of respondent No.3 was as a daily rated
 on the post of Upper Division Teacher on 14/09/1983 for a period of 2
 months. Thereafter, vide order dated 03/10/1985, she was given
 appointment on the post of Upper Division Teacher on adhoc basis for a
 period of six months in pay scale of Rs.740-1180/-. Therefore, it was
 clear that she was not having eligibility to hold the post of Upper
 Division Teacher. Gross irregularities have been committed by the
 Authorities in posting the respondent No.3 as Upper Division Teacher.
 Petitioner has been superseded, therefore, she has filed this petition.

 6. It is further pointed out that respondent No.3 has filed Writ
 Petition No.1199/1995 claiming salary of the post of Lecturer with
 effect from 01/07/1992. The Division Bench of this Court vide order
 dated 12/11/1986 has directed the respondents to make payment of
 officiating allowance or salary as she was working on the post of
 Lecturer from 01/07/1992 and it was further directed that if the
 petitioner is eligible and qualified to be considered for promotion to the
 said post subject to vacancy with respondents for the post of Lecturer,
 she be considered for promotion by holding D.P.C. In pursuant to the
 said order, the Authorities misinterpreted the direction given by the
 Court and wrongly extended the benefit of promotion on the post of
 Lecturer to respondent No.3 de hors the Rules.

 7. The minutes of DPC dated 10/05/2006 are placed before the Court
 pointing out the fact that against first vacancy of the post of Lecturer
 (Political Science), name of respondent No.3 was recommended
 whereas, against second vacancy, Mr. B.L. Khare is performing his
 duties. Name of petitioner was kept in waiting list at S.No.1. Petitioner

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 5 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 has already been extended the benefit of Kramonnati scale on
 completion of 12 years in terms of Rules by order dated 12/12/1997. It
 is argued that as the petitioner is senior to respondent No.3, in all
 fairness, the case of petitioner should have been considered by the
 Authorities. Even Mr. B.L. Khare, who was working as Lecturer
 (Economics) who was also directed to work as Lecturer (Political
 Science) against the vacant post, has retired on attaining the age of
 superannuation on 30/10/2006. Therefore post of Lecturer has fallen
 vacant. The Authorities should have picked up the petitioner from
 waiting list and should have extended the benefit. Therefore, this
 petition has been filed seeking quashment of promotion of respondent
 No.3.

 8. On being noticed, a reply has been filed by respondent No.1
 denying all the petition averments. It is pointed out that respondent No.3
 was initially appointed on 14/09/1983 as Upper Division Teacher. Vide
 order dated 05/02/1987, she was appointed as Upper Division Teacher
 in the pay scale of Rs.575-880/-. Instead of confirming her appointment
 on the post of Upper Division Teacher, she was subsequently appointed
 as Upper Division Teacher subject to approval of Public Service
 Commission. Respondent No.3 assailed the orders by filing M.P.
 No.4863/1989 which was finally decided on 26/07/1991 and the
 Division Bench of this Court was pleaded to quash the order dated
 04/08/1987 directing the Authorities i.e. Corporation to treat the
 respondent No.3 (petitioner therein) duly appointed on the post of
 Teacher from the date of her initial appointment and to pay her all the
 remaining benefits. The said order has attained finality as was never
 challenged before any Forum. The said order is not brought to the

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 6 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 knowledge of this Court by filing this petition. In view of the order
 passed by Division Bench of this Court, respondent No.3 was treated as
 UDT from the date of initial appointment. The Corporation has accepted
 the appointment of respondent No.3 on the post of UDT from the date of
 her initial appointment. Accordingly, the seniority list was prepared and
 respondent No.3 was placed above petitioner in the seniority list. The
 order dated 12/11/1986 was prior to order dated 05/02/1987, therefore,
 the Authorities have followed the order passed by Division Bench.
 Again W.P. No.119/1995 was filed by respondent No.3 which was
 decided on 22/11/2005 directing the Authorities to consider her case for
 promotion to the post of Lecturer if she is found eligible and qualified to
 be considered for promotion to the said post subject to vacancy by
 holding DPC. In pursuance of the order, DPC has been constituted on
 10/05/2006 and respondent No.3 was found eligible on the basis of
 seniority/ suitability and her name was recommended for the post of
 Lecturer. Name of petitioner was also taken into consideration by DPC
 and after according approval from the State Government, promotion of
 respondent No.3 was ordered. Therefore, the entire procedure has been
 followed by the Authorities and in compliance of judgment passed by
 Division Bench of this Court, respondent No.3 was found suitable for
 grant of promotion in the DPC constituted on 10/05/2006. There is no
 challenge by the petitioner to the seniority list prepared by the
 Authorities in pursuance to the direction given by Division Bench of
 this Court wherein the Authorities were directed to treat respondent
 No.3 as a Teacher from her initial date of appointment, therefore prayed
 for dismissal of Writ Petition.

 9. Respondent No.3 has filed her separate reply denying the petition

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 7 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 averments and virtually reiterating the contentions made by respondent
 No.1. Apart from aforesaid, it is further contended that she is having
 qualification of M.A. in Political Science (Second Division), B.Ed. and
 MMA in Philosophy (Second Division) whereas, petitioner is having
 M.A. in Police Science (Third Division) and B.Ed. Hence, respondent
 No.3 is having higher qualification than the petitioner. There is no
 dispute with respect to initial appointment of respondent No.3 on
 05/02/1987. In stead of confirming her appointment, the Authorities
 have again appointed her as Upper Division Teacher, therefore she was
 forced to file petition before the Court and Division Bench of this Court
 has quashed the order dated 04/08/1987 directing the Corporation to
 treat the petitioner therein i.e. respondent No.3 as duly appointed to the
 post of Teacher from the date of her initial appointment and to pay her
 all monetary benefits arising therefrom. Thereafter the entire exercise
 has been taken by the Authorities in pursuant to the order passed by
 Division Bench of this Court. There is no illegality in granting
 promotion to respondent No.3 treating her senior to the petitioner.

 10. Rejoinder has been filed by petitioner denying the contentions in
 the return further contending therein that even if respondent No.3 is
 given seniority with effect from the date of adhoc appointment i.e. from
 the date of her appointment as Upper Division Teacher, she will be
 junior to the petitioner. Therefore, the consideration by the Authorities
 in granting promotion to respondent No.3 is per se illegal.

 11. Heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record.

 12. Apart from the admitted position regarding appointment of
 petitioner as well as respondent No.3, record indicates that respondent
 No.3 filed M.P. No.4863/1989 challenging the order dated 04/08/1987

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 8 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 issued by the respondents whereby she was appointed as Upper Division
 Teacher on adhoc basis. The said M.P. was finally decided by Division
 Bench of this Court on 26/07/1991 holding as under:-

 "4. Learned counsel appearing for the Municipal
 Corporation made a feeble attempt to support the
 case of the Corp. stating that the petitioner did not
 possess the requisite qualification for the post.
 Having considered the submissions made by the
 counsel for the parties we are of the opinion that
 the petition deserves to succeed. We find
 substance in the contention of the petitioner that
 having possessed second division in B.Ed. she was
 qualified for the post. We are also of the opinion
 that even if there was any such qualification
 prescribed in the rules applicable to Govt. teachers,
 which were adopted by the Municipal Corporation,
 the Corporation having continued her for such a
 long period to work on the post of teacher, the
 qualifications prescribed if any, were impliedly
 relaxed in her case. The petitioner is entitled to be
 regularised on the post of Upper Division Teacher
 on the basis of her long continuance on the post.
 The respondent/ Corporation could not dispute the
 fact that even after her appointment as Upper
 Division Clerk she was discharging the duties of a
 teacher in the school.

 5. Consequently, the petition is allowed. The
 impugned orders issued by the Municipal
 Corporation dated 5/2/1987 (Annexure-H) and
 dated 4/8/1987 (Annexure-K) are hereby quashed.
 It is directed that the Corporation shall treat the
 petitioner as duly appointed to the post of teacher
 with effect from her initial appointment in the
 Corporation and pay her all monetary benefits
 arising therefrom. The petitioner shall also get
 costs of this petition. Counsel fee Rs.500/-, if
 certified."

 13. In pursuance to the order passed by Division Bench of this Court,

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 9 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 an order was passed by the Commissioner on 01/08/1991 treating her
 appointment to be justified and considered her appointment from the
 initial date of appointment i.e. 14/09/1983. The said order has never
 been challenged by the respondents or by the petitioner at any point of
 time and the same has attained finality. Thereafter, Authorities have
 prepared the seniority list and finding the respondent No.3 to be the
 senior, she was placed over and above the petitioner. The DPC was
 constituted and the name of respondent No.3 finds place at S.No.1 in the
 seniority list and petitioner's name finds place at S.No.3 under the
 category of UDT. The said list has never been challenged by the
 petitioner. Thereafter, again a Writ Petition has been filed being W.P.
 No.1199/1995 by respondent No.3 against non-payment of salary of the
 post of Lecturer with effect from 01/07/1992 which was decided on
 22/11/2005 with the following directions:-

 "On careful consideration of the submissions and
 the pleadings made by the petitioner, I am of the
 view that it is a fit case which requires directions to
 be given to the respondent to consider the claim of
 the petitioner for payment of salary or officiating
 allowance to her for the post of lecturer as she is
 working in the aforesaid post with effect from 1.7.92.
 In the present case no return has been filed by the
 respondent and therefore there is no denial before
 this court about the fact that the petitioner is not
 working on the post of Lecturer with effect from
 1.7.92. The counsel for the petitioner had not been
 able to point out any order of promotion by which the
 petitioner was appointed to the post of Lecturer but
 had demonstrated from the time table for the various
 years which are annexures P-2 and P-3 and on that
 basis it is clear that the petitioner had been working
 on the post of Lecturer.

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 10 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 In view of the aforesaid, the respondents are
 directed to consider the grant of officiating allowance
 or salaries to the petitioner as she is working on the
 post of Lecturer from 1.7.92 and further to consider
 her promotion to the post of Lecturer if the petitioner
 is eligible and qualified to be considered for
 promotion to the said post subject to the vacancy
 with respondent for the post of lecturer by holding a
 DPC. The same may be done within a period of 3
 months from the date of producing certified copy of
 this order to the respondents.

 The petition is disposed of with no order as to
 costs."

 14. While disposing of the Writ Petition, apart from granting benefit
 of salary/ officiating allowance of the post of Lecturer, further direction
 was issued to consider her case for promotion by holding a DPC. The
 aforesaid facts are not controverted by the petitioner. Record indicates
 that petitioner's initial appointment to the post of Upper Division
 Teacher was on 23/09/1983 and the initial appointment of respondent
 No.3 was on 14/09/1983 i.e. admittedly prior to that of petitioner. The
 respondent/Corporation has complied with the direction issued by
 Division Bench of this Court in M.P. No.4863/1989 which is admittedly
 subsequent to the order dated 12/11/1986 passed by Division Bench of
 this Court in M.P. No.519/1986. The said petition was regarding her
 appointment to the post in question, wherein observations were made
 that petitioner is 3rd Class Graduate and 3rd Division in Higher
 Secondary School Examination. Therefore, no relief was granted to her.
 The fact remains that documents which are being filed along with return
 of respondent No.3 shows that respondent No.3 is M.A. in Political
 Science (Second Division). Thus, the aforesaid averment in that order is
 factually incorrect. Apart from aforesaid, Division Bench has already

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 11 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 passed the subsequent order dated 26/07/1991 in M.P. No.4863/1989,
 quashing the order dated 04/08/1987 issued by the Authorities
 considering the petitioner as officiating UDT.

 15. In absence of any challenge to the seniority list coupled with the
 fact that entire exercise was done by the Corporation in pursuant to the
 direction given by Division bench, no case for interference is made out
 in this petition. Thus, no relief can be extended to the petitioner.

 16. The petition sans merit and is accordingly dismissed. No order as
 to costs.

 W.P. No.13741/2016

 17. In W.P. No.13741/2016, petitioner has prayed for following
 relief(s):-

 (i) Hon'ble Court may kindly be pleased to direct
 the respondents to consider the case of the
 petitioner for promotion to the post of Lecturer
 Political Science in the same D.P.C. scheduled
 to be held pursuant to the decision of Mayor-in-

 Council dated 30.06.2016 and if she is found
 suitable, the order of promotion may kindly be
 directed to be issued giving her promotion to the
 post of Lecturer Political Science alongwith all
 consequential benefits, or alternatively, they
 may be directed not to consider the case of
 promotion of Smt. Kamlesh Choubey to the post
 of Principal in the D.P.C. till the final disposal
 of W.P. No.9715/2007(S).

 (ii) Any other writ, order or direction, which this
 Hon'ble Court deems fit and proper in the facts
 and circumstances of the case, may also kindly
 be passed, in the interest of justice.

 18. The entire case of the petitioner is based upon challenge to the
 appointment of Smt. Kamlesh Choubey as well as her seniority.

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: SHUBHANKAR

MISHRA

Signing time: 03-12-2024

18:45:11

 NEUTRAL CITATION NO. 2024:MPHC-JBP:58767

 12 W.P. No.9715/2007

 & W.P. No.13741/2016

 19. The fact remains that this Court in connected Writ Petition
 No.9715/2007 has considered the aspect and has dismissed the Writ
 Petition filed by the petitioner holding that the entire exercise done by
 the Corporation was in view of the judgment passed by Division Bench
 of this Court. Therefore, no benefit could have been extended to the
 petitioner.

 20. Once the respondent No.4 - Smt. Kamlesh Choubey is found to
 be senior to the petitioner and her name was placed over and above the
 petitioner in seniority list which has never been put to challenge, no
 ground for consideration of name of petitioner over and above
 respondent No.4 is made out. The appointment of petitioner on the post
 of Upper Division Teacher has been upheld by Division Bench of this
 Court in earlier round of litigation as well as the fact that she has been
 placed over and above the petitioner, direction to the respondents to
 consider the name of petitioner in the promotion drive could not have
 been done specifically in the circumstances when admittedly respondent
 No.4's name finds place over and above the petitioner in the seniority
 list.

 21. Therefore, non-consideration of petitioner's name by DPC does
 not call for any interference in the present petition.

 22. The petition sans merit and is accordingly dismissed. No order as
 to costs.

 (VISHAL MISHRA)
 JUDGE

appointment of respondent No.3 is not approved by Public Service

 petition has been filed seeking quashment of promotion of respondent
 No.3.

8. On being noticed, a reply has been filed by respondent No.1
 denying all the petition averments. It is pointed out that respondent No.3
 was initially appointed on 14/09/1983 as Upper Division Teacher. Vide
 order dated 05/02/1987, she was appointed as Upper Division Teacher
 in the pay scale of Rs.575-880/-. Instead of confirming her appointment
 on the post of Upper Division Teacher, she was subsequently appointed
 as Upper Division Teacher subject to approval of Public Service
 Commission. Respondent No.3 assailed the orders by filing M.P.
 No.4863/1989 which was finally decided on 26/07/1991 and the
 Division Bench of this Court was pleaded to quash the order dated
 04/08/1987 directing the Authorities i.e. Corporation to treat the
 respondent No.3 (petitioner therein) duly appointed on the post of
 Teacher from the date of her initial appointment and to pay her all the
 remaining benefits. The said order has attained finality as was never
 challenged before any Forum. The said order is not brought to the

knowledge of this Court by filing this petition. In view of the order
 passed by Division Bench of this Court, respondent No.3 was treated as
 UDT from the date of initial appointment. The Corporation has accepted
 the appointment of respondent No.3 on the post of UDT from the date of
 her initial appointment. Accordingly, the seniority list was prepared and
 respondent No.3 was placed above petitioner in the seniority list. The
 order dated 12/11/1986 was prior to order dated 05/02/1987, therefore,
 the Authorities have followed the order passed by Division Bench.
 Again W.P. No.119/1995 was filed by respondent No.3 which was
 decided on 22/11/2005 directing the Authorities to consider her case for
 promotion to the post of Lecturer if she is found eligible and qualified to
 be considered for promotion to the said post subject to vacancy by
 holding DPC. In pursuance of the order, DPC has been constituted on
 10/05/2006 and respondent No.3 was found eligible on the basis of
 seniority/ suitability and her name was recommended for the post of
 Lecturer. Name of petitioner was also taken into consideration by DPC
 and after according approval from the State Government, promotion of
 respondent No.3 was ordered. Therefore, the entire procedure has been
 followed by the Authorities and in compliance of judgment passed by
 Division Bench of this Court, respondent No.3 was found suitable for
 grant of promotion in the DPC constituted on 10/05/2006. There is no
 challenge by the petitioner to the seniority list prepared by the
 Authorities in pursuance to the direction given by Division Bench of
 this Court wherein the Authorities were directed to treat respondent
 No.3 as a Teacher from her initial date of appointment, therefore prayed
 for dismissal of Writ Petition.
9. Respondent No.3 has filed her separate reply denying the petition

averments and virtually reiterating the contentions made by respondent
 No.1. Apart from aforesaid, it is further contended that she is having
 qualification of M.A. in Political Science (Second Division), B.Ed. and
 MMA in Philosophy (Second Division) whereas, petitioner is having
 M.A. in Police Science (Third Division) and B.Ed. Hence, respondent
 No.3 is having higher qualification than the petitioner. There is no
 dispute with respect to initial appointment of respondent No.3 on
 05/02/1987. In stead of confirming her appointment, the Authorities
 have again appointed her as Upper Division Teacher, therefore she was
 forced to file petition before the Court and Division Bench of this Court
 has quashed the order dated 04/08/1987 directing the Corporation to
 treat the petitioner therein i.e. respondent No.3 as duly appointed to the
 post of Teacher from the date of her initial appointment and to pay her
 all monetary benefits arising therefrom. Thereafter the entire exercise
 has been taken by the Authorities in pursuant to the order passed by
 Division Bench of this Court. There is no illegality in granting
 promotion to respondent No.3 treating her senior to the petitioner.

10. Rejoinder has been filed by petitioner denying the contentions in
 the return further contending therein that even if respondent No.3 is
 given seniority with effect from the date of adhoc appointment i.e. from
 the date of her appointment as Upper Division Teacher, she will be
 junior to the petitioner. Therefore, the consideration by the Authorities
 in granting promotion to respondent No.3 is per se illegal.
11. Heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record.

12. Apart from the admitted position regarding appointment of
 petitioner as well as respondent No.3, record indicates that respondent
 No.3 filed M.P. No.4863/1989 challenging the order dated 04/08/1987

issued by the respondents whereby she was appointed as Upper Division
 Teacher on adhoc basis. The said M.P. was finally decided by Division
 Bench of this Court on 26/07/1991 holding as under:-

"4. Learned counsel appearing for the Municipal
 Corporation made a feeble attempt to support the
 case of the Corp. stating that the petitioner did not
 possess the requisite qualification for the post.
 Having considered the submissions made by the
 counsel for the parties we are of the opinion that
 the petition deserves to succeed. We find
 substance in the contention of the petitioner that
 having possessed second division in B.Ed. she was
 qualified for the post. We are also of the opinion
 that even if there was any such qualification
 prescribed in the rules applicable to Govt. teachers,
 which were adopted by the Municipal Corporation,
 the Corporation having continued her for such a
 long period to work on the post of teacher, the
 qualifications prescribed if any, were impliedly
 relaxed in her case. The petitioner is entitled to be
 regularised on the post of Upper Division Teacher
 on the basis of her long continuance on the post.
 The respondent/ Corporation could not dispute the
 fact that even after her appointment as Upper
 Division Clerk she was discharging the duties of a
 teacher in the school.

5. Consequently, the petition is allowed. The
 impugned orders issued by the Municipal
 Corporation dated 5/2/1987 (Annexure-H) and
 dated 4/8/1987 (Annexure-K) are hereby quashed.
 It is directed that the Corporation shall treat the
 petitioner as duly appointed to the post of teacher
 with effect from her initial appointment in the
 Corporation and pay her all monetary benefits
 arising therefrom. The petitioner shall also get
 costs of this petition. Counsel fee Rs.500/-, if
 certified."
13. In pursuance to the order passed by Division Bench of this Court,

an order was passed by the Commissioner on 01/08/1991 treating her
 appointment to be justified and considered her appointment from the
 initial date of appointment i.e. 14/09/1983. The said order has never
 been challenged by the respondents or by the petitioner at any point of
 time and the same has attained finality. Thereafter, Authorities have
 prepared the seniority list and finding the respondent No.3 to be the
 senior, she was placed over and above the petitioner. The DPC was
 constituted and the name of respondent No.3 finds place at S.No.1 in the
 seniority list and petitioner's name finds place at S.No.3 under the
 category of UDT. The said list has never been challenged by the
 petitioner. Thereafter, again a Writ Petition has been filed being W.P.
 No.1199/1995 by respondent No.3 against non-payment of salary of the
 post of Lecturer with effect from 01/07/1992 which was decided on
 22/11/2005 with the following directions:-

"On careful consideration of the submissions and
 the pleadings made by the petitioner, I am of the
 view that it is a fit case which requires directions to
 be given to the respondent to consider the claim of
 the petitioner for payment of salary or officiating
 allowance to her for the post of lecturer as she is
 working in the aforesaid post with effect from 1.7.92.
 In the present case no return has been filed by the
 respondent and therefore there is no denial before
 this court about the fact that the petitioner is not
 working on the post of Lecturer with effect from
 1.7.92. The counsel for the petitioner had not been
 able to point out any order of promotion by which the
 petitioner was appointed to the post of Lecturer but
 had demonstrated from the time table for the various
 years which are annexures P-2 and P-3 and on that
 basis it is clear that the petitioner had been working
 on the post of Lecturer.

In view of the aforesaid, the respondents are
 directed to consider the grant of officiating allowance
 or salaries to the petitioner as she is working on the
 post of Lecturer from 1.7.92 and further to consider
 her promotion to the post of Lecturer if the petitioner
 is eligible and qualified to be considered for
 promotion to the said post subject to the vacancy
 with respondent for the post of lecturer by holding a
 DPC. The same may be done within a period of 3
 months from the date of producing certified copy of
 this order to the respondents.

The petition is disposed of with no order as to
 costs."

14. While disposing of the Writ Petition, apart from granting benefit
 of salary/ officiating allowance of the post of Lecturer, further direction
 was issued to consider her case for promotion by holding a DPC. The
 aforesaid facts are not controverted by the petitioner. Record indicates
 that petitioner's initial appointment to the post of Upper Division
 Teacher was on 23/09/1983 and the initial appointment of respondent
 No.3 was on 14/09/1983 i.e. admittedly prior to that of petitioner. The
 respondent/Corporation has complied with the direction issued by
 Division Bench of this Court in M.P. No.4863/1989 which is admittedly
 subsequent to the order dated 12/11/1986 passed by Division Bench of
 this Court in M.P. No.519/1986. The said petition was regarding her
 appointment to the post in question, wherein observations were made
 that petitioner is 3rd Class Graduate and 3rd Division in Higher
 Secondary School Examination. Therefore, no relief was granted to her.
 The fact remains that documents which are being filed along with return
 of respondent No.3 shows that respondent No.3 is M.A. in Political
 Science (Second Division). Thus, the aforesaid averment in that order is
 factually incorrect. Apart from aforesaid, Division Bench has already

passed the subsequent order dated 26/07/1991 in M.P. No.4863/1989,
 quashing the order dated 04/08/1987 issued by the Authorities
 considering the petitioner as officiating UDT.

15. In absence of any challenge to the seniority list coupled with the
 fact that entire exercise was done by the Corporation in pursuant to the
 direction given by Division bench, no case for interference is made out
 in this petition. Thus, no relief can be extended to the petitioner.

16. The petition sans merit and is accordingly dismissed. No order as
 to costs.

17. In W.P. No.13741/2016, petitioner has prayed for following
 relief(s):-

(i) Hon'ble Court may kindly be pleased to direct
 the respondents to consider the case of the
 petitioner for promotion to the post of Lecturer
 Political Science in the same D.P.C. scheduled
 to be held pursuant to the decision of Mayor-in-

Council dated 30.06.2016 and if she is found
 suitable, the order of promotion may kindly be
 directed to be issued giving her promotion to the
 post of Lecturer Political Science alongwith all
 consequential benefits, or alternatively, they
 may be directed not to consider the case of
 promotion of Smt. Kamlesh Choubey to the post
 of Principal in the D.P.C. till the final disposal
 of W.P. No.9715/2007(S).

(ii) Any other writ, order or direction, which this
 Hon'ble Court deems fit and proper in the facts
 and circumstances of the case, may also kindly
 be passed, in the interest of justice.

18. The entire case of the petitioner is based upon challenge to the
 appointment of Smt. Kamlesh Choubey as well as her seniority.

19. The fact remains that this Court in connected Writ Petition
 No.9715/2007 has considered the aspect and has dismissed the Writ
 Petition filed by the petitioner holding that the entire exercise done by
 the Corporation was in view of the judgment passed by Division Bench
 of this Court. Therefore, no benefit could have been extended to the
 petitioner.

20. Once the respondent No.4 - Smt. Kamlesh Choubey is found to
 be senior to the petitioner and her name was placed over and above the
 petitioner in seniority list which has never been put to challenge, no
 ground for consideration of name of petitioner over and above
 respondent No.4 is made out. The appointment of petitioner on the post
 of Upper Division Teacher has been upheld by Division Bench of this
 Court in earlier round of litigation as well as the fact that she has been
 placed over and above the petitioner, direction to the respondents to
 consider the name of petitioner in the promotion drive could not have
 been done specifically in the circumstances when admittedly respondent
 No.4's name finds place over and above the petitioner in the seniority
 list.

21. Therefore, non-consideration of petitioner's name by DPC does
 not call for any interference in the present petition.

22. The petition sans merit and is accordingly dismissed. No order as
 to costs.
